name: The Umbrella
description_html: Umbrellas became a defining symbol of the 2014 Hong Kong pro-democracy protests – soon dubbed the “Umbrella Movement” or “Umbrella Revolution”. When police first fired tear-gas canisters at student-led sit-ins on 28 September 2014, demonstrators instinctively raised umbrellas to block pepper spray, rubber bullets, and the blazing midday sun, turning an everyday accessory into an emblem of passive resistance and the fight for universal suffrage. Images of pastel-colored canopies clustered outside government headquarters in Admiralty – and later across Mong Kok and Causeway Bay – spread worldwide, capturing the movement’s creativity and determination. Yellow umbrellas, especially, became shorthand for the cause: they appeared in protest art, were projected onto skyscrapers, and even inspired the 3-metre-tall “Umbrella Man” statue erected in the occupied streets. Beyond defence, umbrellas served as makeshift banners for slogans such as “I want real democracy,” and were lashed together into improvised barricades or held high to shield protesters’ faces from surveillance cameras. The symbolism soon travelled: activists in Myanmar, Thailand, and elsewhere have since wielded umbrellas in their own demonstrations, using them both for physical protection and as a vivid visual link to Hong Kong’s precedent.

images.caption: Yellow umbrellas outside government headquarters, Admiralty, 2014
Umbrella revolution 2014. Photo by johnlam
Crowd assembled during sit-in, Mong Kok
A line of umbrellas forming a barrier
A line of umbrellas forming a barrier
Short clip: umbrella moment (YouTube)

eyewitness: I was standing near Admiralty when the students first raised umbrellas — the crowd was calm but determined. (Anonymous eyewitness, 2014)
Several people I spoke with described how umbrellas were used both to shield from tear gas and to protect identities from cameras.

sources.title: Coverage of the Umbrella Movement

sources: Chan, L. (2015). Visual symbols in protest movements. Journal of Social Movements.

sources.title: Documentary excerpt (video)

name: The White Head Scarf
description_html: In 1977 Argentina’s Mothers of Plaza de Mayo donned white scarves—evoking diapers—to mark the innocence of children who disappeared under military rule. Their weekly marches in Buenos Aires turned the scarf into a global emblem of the quest for truth and justice. In Iran, white scarves signal defiance of compulsory hijab laws. Spurred by #WhiteWednesdays, women wore or waved white scarves to protest mandatory veiling. The gesture drew worldwide attention in 2017 when Vida Movahed, the “Girl of Enghelab Street,” stood unveiled and brandished her scarf, inspiring similar protests and arrests.

name: The Blank Sheet of Paper
description_html: A white piece of paper, or blank sheet, has become a powerful symbol of protest against censorship and repression, most notably during the 2022 anti-lockdown demonstrations in China. Protesters held up blank sheets to silently express everything they were forbidden to say, making the absence of words a direct metaphor for silenced voices and government control. The tactic originated earlier in the 2019–2020 Hong Kong protests, where demonstrators used blank paper after protest slogans were banned. The symbol has since appeared in other countries.

name: Vinegar
description_html: Vinegar became an emblematic tool during the 2013 protests in Brazil, often called the “Vinegar Protests” (Revolta do Vinagre). Protesters carried bottles of vinegar, believing that breathing through a cloth soaked in vinegar could help neutralize the effects of tear gas and pepper spray used by police, though its medical effectiveness is debated. The tactic became so widespread that police arrested over 60 people for carrying vinegar, including journalists, turning the substance into a symbol of resistance and sparking sarcastic nicknames like “the vinegar march”.

images.caption: Yellow umbrellas outside government headquarters, Admiralty, 2014

name: Brazilian football jersey
description_html: The yellow Brazilian football jersey, traditionally a unifying national symbol, has been controversially co-opted as a protest symbol in recent years. Most notably, supporters of former President Jair Bolsonaro adopted the jersey during political rallies and protests, including the storming of government buildings in Brasília in January 2023. The jersey, once seen as non-partisan, became closely linked to right-wing and nationalist movements, leading to widespread controversy and debate over its meaning. The Brazilian Football Confederation publicly condemned the politicization of the jersey, emphasizing its intended role to unite, not divide, Brazilians.

images.caption: Yellow umbrellas outside government headquarters, Admiralty, 2014

name: Keys
description_html: In Czech protests, especially those harkening back to the 1989 Velvet Revolution, rattling keys became a symbolic act of defiance, representing the end of Communist-era surveillance (keys to locked-down lives) and a call for transparency, with protesters shaking them in squares like Wenceslas Square to demand change and echo democratic ideals. This tradition continues in modern demonstrations, linking current demands for accountability (like against then-PM Babiš in 2019) with the legacy of freedom from 1989.

images.caption: Yellow umbrellas outside government headquarters, Admiralty, 2014
Crowd assembled during sit-in, Mong Kok

name: Fireworks
description_html: During Georgia’s 2024–25 pro-EU protests, fireworks have become both rallying beacon and improvised weapon. Night after night in Tbilisi—and in smaller rallies in Batumi and Kutaisi—thousands launch rockets skyward or toward police cordons outside parliament. The crackling bursts energise crowds, mask tear-gas plumes, and disrupt water-cannon advances. Protesters frame the pyrotechnics as a non-lethal form of self-defence and defiance; riot police answer with tear gas, stun grenades, and mass arrests. The salvos have so unsettled officials that Prime Minister Irakli Kobakhidze has ordered an emergency ban on retail fireworks, accusing shops of “arming a revolution,” while rights groups argue the measure merely criminalises dissent. In this clash of light and law, fireworks have come to symbolise the creativity—and determination—of Georgia’s EU-leaning generation.

images.caption: Yellow umbrellas outside government headquarters, Admiralty, 2014
Crowd assembled during sit-in, Mong Kok
A line of umbrellas forming a barrier
A line of umbrellas forming a barrier
Short clip: umbrella moment (YouTube)

eyewitness: I was standing near Admiralty when the students first raised umbrellas — the crowd was calm but determined. (Anonymous eyewitness, 2014)
Several people I spoke with described how umbrellas were used both to shield from tear gas and to protect identities from cameras.

sources.title: Documentary excerpt (video)

name: The Watermelon
description_html: The watermelon has become a creative stand-in for the Palestinian flag: its red flesh, green rind, white pith, and black seeds echo the flag’s four colours. After Israel outlawed public displays of the Palestinian flag and even its colour combination following the 1967 Six-Day War, Palestinians began painting, carrying, and photographing watermelon slices to sidestep the ban and signal national identity. The fruit soon appeared in murals, posters, and street rallies. During the 2023 Gaza conflict, its image and emoji spread globally online, letting supporters show solidarity and evade censorship when the flag itself was still forbidden.

name: The Coat Hanger
description_html: A coat hanger is a powerful and enduring symbol in abortion rights protests, representing the dangers of unsafe, illegal abortions. Its origins as a protest icon date back to the pre-Roe v. Wade era in the United States, when women sometimes resorted to using wire coat hangers to self-induce abortions due to lack of access to safe medical procedures. The coat hanger thus serves as a stark warning of the life-threatening risks women face when abortion is criminalized. Activists have prominently featured coat hangers in demonstrations, such as the 1969 Washington march where protesters wore them around their necks and in more recent actions, including sending hangers to the U.S. Supreme Court. In Poland, coat hangers have also become a central visual element in protests against abortion bans. During the 2016 “Black Monday” strike and subsequent demonstrations, Polish women held up wire coat hangers to represent the peril of illegal abortions, warning against the consequences of restrictive legislation. The use of coat hangers in both American and Polish contexts underscores their role as a universal symbol of resistance to abortion bans and a call for safe, legal reproductive healthcare.

name: Chrysanthemums & Asters
description_html: Chrysanthemums and their close relative, asters, have occasionally served as protest emblems, drawing on their associations with remembrance or peaceful resistance. The clearest political use came in Hungary’s 1918 Aster Revolution, when supporters pinned asters to their coats while proclaiming the First Hungarian People’s Republic. In East Asia, white chrysanthemums—long linked to mourning—appear at vigils such as Hong Kong’s annual Tiananmen commemorations, honoring those lost in political struggle. A famous Western image is Marc Riboud’s 1967 photograph from the March on the Pentagon, showing 17-year-old Jan Rose Kasmir holding a chrysanthemum in front of soldiers’ bayonets, powerfully representing peaceful resistance during the anti–Vietnam War movement.

name: The Spoon
description_html: The spoon emerged as a powerful symbol of Palestinian resistance following the dramatic escape of six Palestinian prisoners from Israel’s high-security Gilboa Prison in September 2021. According to reports, the escapees used spoons, along with plates and kettle handles, to dig a tunnel from their cell, evading security measures and sparking widespread admiration. The event quickly inspired artists, activists, and demonstrators, who began featuring spoons in protest art, sculptures, and public rallies as an emblem of determination, ingenuity, and the struggle for freedom.

name: The Wooden Spoon
description_html: In Slovakia, the wooden spoon has become a prominent symbol in protests against the restriction of reproductive rights. During demonstrations opposing stricter abortion laws in 2020, organizers encouraged participants to bring wooden spoons—alongside pots and brooms—as a representation of care, domestic labor, and civil disobedience. The spoons were often customized with messages, symbolizing both the everyday work of women and resistance to political attempts to control their bodies. In Burkina Faso, the wooden spoon has also been used as a protest symbol, particularly by women who bang them against pots to make noise and draw attention to their demands. This act, rooted in local traditions, highlights the role of women in civic action and protest.

name: The Rubber Duck
description_html: Rubber ducks became an iconic symbol of Thailand’s pro-democracy protests in 2020. Initially brought to demonstrations as a humorous response to government barricades, inflatable yellow ducks quickly gained prominence when protesters used them as improvised shields against police water cannons and tear gas during violent clashes near parliament. Their cheerful, fragile appearance contrasted with their new role as protectors, capturing public imagination and inspiring widespread protest art and memes.

name: The Yellow Ribbon
description_html: Yellow ribbons have historically symbolized hope for a loved one’s safe return. In the 1980s, they became a sign of democratization in the Philippines. After the 2014 Sewol Ferry disaster in South Korea, they spread online as a symbol of hope, later evolving into a protest icon as public anger toward the government grew, representing grief and the demand for accountability. Since 2022, Ukraine’s “Yellow Ribbon” resistance movement has used the symbol in russian-occupied territories. Tied in public spaces, the ribbons express support for Ukrainian sovereignty and serve as quiet signs of unity and nonviolent resistance.

name: The Water Jug
description_html: The water jug has emerged as an unexpected symbol in pro-Palestinian protests across the United States, particularly during the wave of student-led demonstrations in 2024 and 2025. Its rise began with viral incidents at university protests, most notably at California Polytechnic State University, Humboldt, where a protester struck a police officer with a large, empty water jug. The moment, captured on video, quickly spread across social media, where the jug was dubbed the “Jug of Justice” and became an emblem of grassroots resistance. Protesters began bringing water jugs to demonstrations, using them as makeshift shields, tools for practical needs, and a symbol of anti-police sentiment and solidarity with the Palestinian cause.

name: Tape
description_html: Tape has become a stark protest symbol. Protesters often place tape over their mouths to represent censorship, forced silence, or the suppression of free speech, making visible the experience of being silenced by authorities or unjust laws. Another notable example of tape’s symbolic use occurred during the 2003 Cricket World Cup when Zimbabwean players Andy Flower and Henry Olonga, lacking black armbands, wore strips of black insulating tape to “mourn the death of democracy,” drawing global attention to government repression. This highlights how an ordinary item can instantly signal profound political dissent.

name: Eggs
description_html: The act of throwing eggs at people or property has a long history as a protest tactic, especially against politicians and public figures. The intention is typically to humiliate the target rather than cause physical harm, turning them into figures of ridicule and signaling moral objection to their actions or presence. Notable incidents include the egging of Winston Churchill by a suffragette in 1910, and various politicians like Richard Nixon, Harold Wilson, and Scott Morrison. Egging is considered vandalism and can result in legal consequences, especially if property is damaged or injuries occur.

name: Flour
description_html: Flour bombing is a classic protest method involving the throwing of flour, often contained in paper bags, at people or objects. This tactic is used to create an inconvenient and messy stain, serving as a form of public humiliation or disruption. Flour bombs have been used alongside eggs in protests against politicians like Tony Blair and Emmanuel Macron, and during major demonstrations, such as the 1981 Springbok Tour in New Zealand. Historically, flour has also been central to food riots, such as the 1837 Flour Riot in New York City, where public anger over rising prices led to mass looting and destruction of flour stores. The tactic remains a simple, non-lethal way to achieve maximum disruption.

name: Soup
description_html: Soup has become a notable tool in climate and social justice protests, particularly in high-profile actions targeting famous artworks in museums. Activists have thrown soup at protected paintings such as Leonardo da Vinci’s Mona Lisa and Vincent van Gogh’s Sunflowers to draw attention to issues like environmental policy and food security. These acts are intended to provoke public debate and highlight the perceived imbalance between the protection of art and urgent social needs. The protests often include statements demanding systemic changes, such as the right to healthy and sustainable food, and are orchestrated by groups aiming to integrate food justice into broader social security systems. The artworks themselves are typically unharmed due to protective glass coverings.

name: Cake and Pie
description_html: Throwing cakes and pies at public figures is a long-standing protest tactic used to ridicule, embarrass, or draw attention to the actions of politicians and celebrities. This form of protest gained prominence in the late 20th century, with activists targeting political and cultural figures to challenge authority through humor and spectacle. Belgian anarchist Noël Godin popularized “patisserie guerrilla,” turning pie-throwing into an art form. Groups like the Biotic Baking Brigade in the U.S. have used pieing to protest against perceived greed or corruption among “titans of power.” Notable incidents span decades, involving figures from William F. Buckley Jr. and Anita Bryant to Bill Gates, highlighting the endurance of this tactic.

name: Milkshakes
description_html: Milkshakes have emerged as a distinctive protest symbol in recent years, particularly in the United Kingdom, where throwing them at public figures has become a widely recognized act of political dissent. This trend gained prominence during the 2019 anti-Brexit and anti-far-right demonstrations. Beyond its anti-Brexit roots, milkshaking has also taken on anti-racist symbolism. Analysts note that while the alt-right has sometimes used milk as a symbol of white supremacy, the act of throwing milkshakes at far-right figures is seen as a form of “political ju-jitsu”—turning the symbolism against them and making them appear foolish. The milkshake thus functions both as a tool of protest and as a visual statement against extremism.

name: Spilled Milk
description_html: Spilling milk as a protest goes back at least to the 1933 “Milk Wars” in Wisconsin, when striking dairy farmers poured cans of milk onto highways to dramatise ruinously low prices. The gesture re-emerged in Europe during the 2008–10 dairy-price crisis: on 16 September 2009 Belgian farmers sprayed about three million litres over fields, and the same week German producers dumped roughly 7,000 litres outside the agriculture ministry in Bonn. Since then the tactic has travelled well beyond Europe. Bangladeshi farmers spilled 3,000 litres on a highway in 2020 to protest soaring feed costs; Nepali producers dumped unsold milk in the streets in early 2024 over unpaid bills; and in Central Java, Indonesia, cooperatives discarded about 50,000 litres a day in late 2024 after cheap imports undercut local supply. A very different constituency has adopted the same spectacle. Beginning in July 2022, the U.K. group Animal Rebellion (now Animal Rising) emptied bottles across the floors of Harrods and Whole Foods to spotlight climate and animal-welfare costs and to press for a shift to plant-based farming. Whether deployed by indebted farmers or by vegan activists, the sight of good milk running down a drain remains a potent, non-violent symbol of a broken market or environmental harm.

images.caption: Farmers dumping milk during the Wisconsin Milk Strike, 1933
Belgian farmers spraying milk over fields near Ciney, 2009
Activists emptying milk bottles in a luxury department store, London
News report: Dairy farmers dump milk in protest (YouTube)

name: Shoe Throwing
description_html: Shoe-throwing is a widely recognized act of protest and symbolic defiance, particularly since the early 21st century. This gesture is rooted in the cultural significance of shoes as objects associated with insult and contempt in many societies, especially in the Middle East. The most famous incident occurred in 2008, when Iraqi journalist Muntadhar al-Zaidi hurled both his shoes at U.S. President George W. Bush during a Baghdad press conference, declaring it a “farewell kiss” from the Iraqi people. The act was instantly understood as a deep insult, sparking global headlines and inspiring similar political dissent around the world. Since then, the tactic has been adopted in India, Pakistan, Australia, the United Kingdom, and Greece. While it serves as a potent symbol of protest, it remains a polarizing gesture that frequently crosses the line from legitimate dissent to perceived endangerment.

images.caption: The moment journalist Muntadhar al-Zaidi threw his shoes at George W. Bush, 2008
A temporary monument dedicated to the shoe-throwing incident in Tikrit
Protesters leaving shoes outside an embassy as a symbolic mark of disapproval
Footage: The 'Farewell Kiss' in Baghdad (YouTube)

eyewitness: The room went completely silent for a split second before the secret service moved — it was a shock that resonated globally. (Journalist present at the 2008 conference)
In our culture, showing the sole of the shoe is the ultimate sign of disrespect; throwing it is a declaration that the person is beneath the dirt.

sources.title: The Shoe Heard Round the World

sources: Khalidi, R. (2010). Cultural symbols of resistance in the Middle East. Middle Eastern Studies Journal.

sources.title: History of Shoe Throwing as Protest

name: Cleaning Sprays
description_html: During the 2013 Gezi Park protests in Turkey, cleaning sprays were repurposed as emergency medical supplies. As police deployed tear gas and pepper spray, protesters and volunteer medics used cleaning sprays—often filled with water, saline, or vinegar solutions—to rinse eyes and skin, providing quick relief from chemical irritants. This improvisation became a symbol of the protesters’ adaptability and determination to care for each other despite harsh police tactics and limited access to medical care. The sight of protesters carrying these bottles became shorthand for mutual aid and passive resistance in the face of state-led intervention.

images.caption: Protesters using spray bottles to treat victims of tear gas in Gezi Park
A repurposed cleaning bottle labeled for medical use
Documentary: The medical volunteers of Gezi Park (YouTube)

eyewitness: Every time the gas cleared, you’d see dozens of hands reaching out with spray bottles to wash the stinging out of your eyes. (Anonymous protester, Istanbul 2013)
We weren't doctors, but we became experts in neutralizing the effects of pepper spray using whatever bottles we could find.

sources.title: Improvised Medical Care in Occupied Spaces

sources: Korkmaz, E. (2014). The Architecture of Resistance: Mutual Aid in Gezi Park. Turkish Studies Journal.

sources.title: Tactics of the Gezi Park Protests

name: The Whistle
description_html: The whistle is a small but potent tool of protest and self-defence. In classical antiquity, Romans hissed and whistled (sibilare) at gladiatorial games to signal mass disapproval. In modern times, whistles have become standard equipment at demonstrations due to their accessibility. Thailand offers an instructive example: during the 2013–14 “whistle blowing” protests, crowds used plastic whistles to show opposition to the government. Whistles have also been featured in campaigns against anti-Asian violence in the United States. Launched in 2021, The Yellow Whistle initiative distributed bright yellow whistles stamped “WE BELONG” as both an audible alarm and a visible statement of solidarity. By 2024, over 350,000 whistles were distributed to help Asian Americans, particularly elders, broadcast a collective stand against hate. The humble whistle transforms a simple burst of sound into a highly shareable symbol of unity and resistance.

images.caption: Protesters in Bangkok using whistles to signal dissent, 2013
A 'Yellow Whistle' stamped with the words 'WE BELONG' used in NYC
The sound of dissent: Whistles at a rally (YouTube)

eyewitness: The sound was deafening. Thousands of people blowing whistles at once creates a wall of noise that you can feel in your chest. (Bangkok resident, 2014)
Giving these to the grandmothers in Chinatown gave them a sense of agency—a way to scream for help without needing to find their voice.

sources.title: The Yellow Whistle Campaign History

sources: Miller, T. (2016). Sonic Protest: The Role of Noise in Political Change. Global Media Journal.

sources.title: Why the Whistle became Thailand's symbol of revolt

name: Pots and Pans
description_html: Banging pots, pans, and other kitchen utensils—known as cacerolazo in Spanish and panelaço in Portuguese—turns ordinary cookware into a deafening, non-violent show of dissent. The best-documented starting point was Chile’s “March of the Empty Pots and Pans” on 1 December 1971, when women in Santiago highlighted food shortages. During the 1983–1986 period under military rule, Chileans revived the tactic to register dissent from balconies. Argentines used the cacerolazo during the 2001 economic collapse, while Brazilians staged nationwide panelaços in 2015 against corruption. The tactic spread globally: Canada’s 2012 “casseroles” marches, Iceland’s 2008–09 “pots-and-pans revolution”, and Myanmar’s 2021 resistance against the military coup. Loud and inclusive, the rhythmic crash of kitchenware remains a powerful way to voice frustration and demand accountability from private and public spaces.

images.caption: Women banging empty pots in Santiago, Chile, 1971
Massive cacerolazo in Plaza de Mayo, Buenos Aires, 2001
Nightly 'casseroles' march during the Maple Spring, Montreal
The sound of the Panelaço in Brazil (YouTube)

eyewitness: You didn't have to go outside to be part of it. You just opened your window and started hitting the pan with a wooden spoon. Soon, the whole street was ringing. (Santiago resident, 1983)
It is the sound of the kitchen—the heart of the home—demanding to be heard in the halls of power.

sources.title: A History of the Cacerolazo

sources: Garretón, M. (2003). Incomplete Democracy: Political Democratization in Chile and Latin America. University of North Carolina Press.

sources.title: Why Myanmar's residents bang pots at night

name: Rubber Boots
description_html: Rubber boots have become a prominent and evocative symbol in the 2023–2024 German farmers’ protests. As a form of silent protest, farmers hung their boots on town signs, street posts, and farm fences across rural Germany to express dissatisfaction with the abolition of tax breaks and fuel subsidies. The empty boots signify farmers “hanging up their wellies,” a metaphor for ceasing work and a warning of the disappearance of regional food production. This visual gesture also evokes historical uprisings—deliberately referencing the strapped boots (Bundschuh) of the 16th-century Peasants’ War—linking today’s protests to a deeper tradition of rural resistance.

images.caption: Empty rubber boots hanging from a yellow town entrance sign in Germany, 2024
The 'Bundschuh' symbol from the 16th-century Peasants' War
Report: Why German farmers are hanging boots on signs (YouTube)

eyewitness: You drive through the countryside and see these empty boots everywhere. It’s a ghost-like reminder that if we go, the food goes with us. (Bavarian farmer, 2024)
It’s a powerful image because it’s so still. It doesn’t block a road, but it tells you exactly what is at stake.

sources.title: The Symbolism of the Hanging Boot

sources: Blickle, P. (1981). The Revolution of 1525: The German Peasants' War from a New Perspective. Johns Hopkins University Press.

sources.title: Understanding the 2024 Agricultural Crisis

name: Safety Pin
description_html: The safety pin became a widely recognized protest symbol in 2016, first in the United Kingdom after the Brexit vote and then in the United States following the 2016 presidential election. People began wearing safety pins on their clothing as a quiet sign of solidarity with minorities, immigrants, and others who felt threatened by rising discrimination and hate crimes. The pin was intended to signal that the wearer was a “safe person” who would stand up for those facing harassment in public spaces. While praised by many as a simple way to show support, the symbol also faced criticism for being a form of performative activism or “slacktivism” that did not necessarily lead to concrete action.

images.caption: A simple safety pin worn on a coat lapel as a sign of solidarity
Graphic shared on social media explaining the safety pin symbol
The rise of the safety pin symbol (YouTube)

eyewitness: I wore mine on the tube the day after the vote. It was a small way to say 'I'm with you' to people who were suddenly being told they didn't belong. (London resident, 2016)
I saw several people in my office wearing them; it created a silent network of support during a very tense week.

sources.title: Why people are wearing safety pins after Brexit

sources: Ahmed, S. (2017). The Cultural Politics of Emotion. Edinburgh University Press (Chapter on Solidarity).

sources.title: Safety Pins: Solidarity or Slacktivism?

name: Skittles
description_html: Skittles became a symbol in U.S. protests following the 2012 killing of Trayvon Martin, a Black teenager who was shot while carrying a bag of Skittles and a bottle of iced tea. Protesters adopted the candy as an emblem of Martin’s innocence and the injustice of his death, often holding Skittles at rallies and creating memorials. The candy’s colorful appearance came to represent both the loss of innocent life and the broader fight against racial profiling and systemic injustice. Images of Skittles bags were integrated into protest art and hoodies—another symbol of the movement—making the brand a lasting icon in the movement for racial justice in America.

images.caption: A memorial for Trayvon Martin featuring bags of Skittles and iced tea
Protester wearing a hoodie and holding a bag of Skittles, 2012
Video: The symbols of the Trayvon Martin protests (YouTube)

eyewitness: I remember standing in the rain with hundreds of others, everyone holding a bag of Skittles in the air. It was a small thing that felt incredibly heavy. (Protester, Sanford, 2012)
Seeing a child's candy become a piece of evidence in a trial changed how people looked at that red bag forever.

sources.title: How Skittles became a symbol of a movement

sources: Yancy, G. (2013). The Elevator, the Hoodie, and the Trayvon Martin Case. Journal of Social Philosophy.

sources.title: Objects of Resistance in 21st Century America

name: Yellow Vest
description_html: The high-visibility motorist jacket, or gilet jaune, became the central symbol of the “Yellow Vests” movement that began in France in November 2018. Required by law in every vehicle for safety, the vest was adopted for its accessibility, visibility, and working-class associations. Initially triggered by rising fuel taxes and concerns over the cost of living, the movement expanded to broader demands for economic justice. Protesters wore the vests at roadblocks and rallies, turning a mundane safety item into a unifying visual statement. The symbol has since traveled to other countries, representing grassroots discontent and calls for systemic change.

images.caption: Yellow Vest protesters gathered at the Arc de Triomphe, Paris, 2018
A high-visibility vest placed on a car dashboard as a sign of support
The rise of the Gilets Jaunes (YouTube)

eyewitness: We all have one in our cars. It was the easiest way to show we were all in the same boat, struggling to make ends meet at the end of the month. (Protester, Amiens, 2018)
The fluorescent yellow turned the streets into a sea of light; you couldn't ignore us even if you wanted to.

sources.title: Inside the Yellow Vest Movement

sources: Kinniburgh, C. (2019). The Anatomy of a Rebellion: France's Yellow Vests. Dissent Magazine.

sources.title: France's Winter of Discontent

name: The Bra
description_html: The bra became an emblem of feminist protest in the late 1960s, most famously at the 1968 Miss America demonstration in Atlantic City. Activists tossed bras and cosmetics into a “Freedom Trash Can” to denounce unrealistic beauty standards. Although the press coined the phrase “bra-burning feminists,” no items were actually burned. The bra re-emerged as a symbol during Egypt’s 2011 uprising. Footage of security forces dragging a demonstrator in Cairo, her abaya ripped to expose a bright blue bra, provoked nationwide outrage. The “Girl in the Blue Bra” image spurred women-led protests against state violence, turning the garment into a symbol of resilience and female vulnerability.

images.caption: Activists around the 'Freedom Trash Can' at the Miss America protest, 1968
Graffiti of a blue bra in Cairo, symbolizing resistance to military violence
Documentary: The 'Girl in the Blue Bra' and the Egyptian Uprising (YouTube)

eyewitness: We weren't burning anything; we were throwing away the things that bound us, literally and figuratively. (Atlantic City protester, 1968)
That image of the blue bra became our flag. It showed everyone the brutality we were facing on the streets of Cairo.

sources.title: The Myth of the Bra Burners

sources: Hafez, S. (2012). No Longer a Bargain: Women, the State, and the Politics of Public Space in Egypt.

sources.title: How a blue bra shocked a nation

name: Green Bandana
description_html: The green bandana, also known as the green scarf (pañuelo verde), is an internationally recognized symbol of reproductive rights. Originating in Argentina in 2003, it was inspired by the white scarves of the Mothers of the Plaza de Mayo and chosen for its association with hope, life, and renewal. The bandana quickly spread across Latin America as part of the “Green Wave” (Marea Verde) movement, uniting activists in the fight for legal, safe, and free abortion. Its use has since expanded globally, appearing at protests in the United States and Poland, symbolizing solidarity, nonviolent resistance, and the ongoing struggle for bodily autonomy.

images.caption: A sea of green bandanas during a rally in Buenos Aires, Argentina
The 'pañuelo verde' featuring the slogan 'Educación sexual para decidir'
The history of the Green Wave movement (YouTube)

eyewitness: I remember seeing the first few scarves in 2003; we never imagined they would become a uniform for millions of women across the continent. (Argentine activist, 2020)
Tying the bandana to my backpack felt like a secret handshake at first, but soon, everyone on the bus was wearing one.

sources.title: From Argentina to the World: The Green Scarf

sources: Sutton, B. (2020). The Green Wave: Abortion Rights and the Politics of the Body in Argentina. University of California Press.

sources.title: The Visual Language of Modern Feminism

name: One Piece Flag
description_html: The One Piece flag, depicting a grinning skull wearing a straw hat on a black field, is an emerging international symbol of youth-led protest and resistance. Originating in Japanese popular culture as the Jolly Roger of the Straw Hat Pirates, it has been reinterpreted by Generation Z activists for its associations with freedom and defiance against an unjust world order. Since the mid-2020s, the flag has appeared in demonstrations across Indonesia and Nepal to denounce corruption and authoritarian governance. Its narrative link to confronting a corrupt “World Government” allows diverse movements to project local grievances onto a globally recognizable image, turning a manga symbol into a marker of solidarity and nonviolent resistance.

images.caption: Students flying the Straw Hat flag during a rally in Jakarta
Protester in a straw hat holding a sign against social inequality
Analysis: Pop culture symbols in Asian street protests (YouTube)

eyewitness: We don't have a political party, so we use the symbol of the pirates who fight for their friends and for freedom. (University student, Kathmandu, 2024)
Seeing the flag in the crowd makes the protest feel less like a lecture and more like a movement we actually belong to.

sources.title: From Shonen to Street: One Piece in Political Activism

sources: Oda, E. (1997-2026). One Piece. Shueisha (Source material reference).

sources.title: Why Nepal's youth are waving pirate flags

name: The Banana
description_html: In Poland, the banana became a protest icon in April 2019 after Warsaw’s National Museum removed Natalia LL’s 1973 video Consumer Art. Activists condemned the censorship, gathering to eat bananas and posting “banana selfies” online. Historically, during Poland’s 1968 protests, the term “banana youth” (bananowa młodzież) mocked elite children, with the fruit—a rare luxury—symbolizing social divide. Beyond Europe, bananas have long symbolized colonial exploitation in Latin America, epitomized by the 1928 “Banana Massacre” in Colombia, where troops killed striking workers of the United Fruit Company.

images.caption: Crowds eating bananas outside the National Museum in Warsaw, 2019
Still from Natalia LL’s 'Consumer Art' (1973)
Monument to the victims of the 1928 Banana Massacre in Ciénaga
The 'Banana Protest' against censorship in Poland (YouTube)

eyewitness: It started as a joke online, but when we saw thousands of people showing up at the museum with bananas, we realized it was a serious stand against the narrowing of our freedom. (Warsaw activist, 2019)
In 1968, a banana was a sign that your father was a high-ranking official. Today, it's a sign that you won't let officials tell you what art to watch.

sources.title: Censorship and the Banana Protest

sources: García Márquez, G. (1967). One Hundred Years of Solitude. (Literary depiction of the Banana Massacre).

sources.title: The Etymology of Bananowa Młodzież

name: Sardines
description_html: The sardine became a protest symbol in Italy with the birth of the Sardines movement (Movimento delle Sardine) in November 2019. Four friends in Bologna called on people to “pack like sardines” in Piazza Maggiore to outnumber a League rally and show peaceful opposition to Matteo Salvini’s populist rhetoric. Thousands turned up, using the tightly packed crowd as a visual statement of unity against divisive politics. The movement, which rejected formal party structures, used the mockery & satire of being small fish that together become a powerful force to counteract the “sharks” of populism. Similar flash mobs spread across Italy, where protesters held cardboard sardines to represent a silent but massive peaceful resistance.

images.caption: Thousands packed into Piazza Maggiore, Bologna, for the first Sardines rally
Protesters holding colorful cardboard sardines during a demonstration
The flash mob that changed Italian politics (YouTube)

eyewitness: We wanted to show that the 'silent majority' wasn't silent anymore, but we didn't want to shout. We just wanted to be there, packed together like fish. (Bologna activist, 2019)
Seeing a square full of people holding up cardboard fish instead of party flags was a breath of fresh air for Italian democracy.

sources.title: Who are the Italian Sardines?

sources: Santoro, M. (2020). The Sardines: A New Form of Italian Activism. Contemporary Italian Politics Journal.

sources.title: Visual Satire in Modern Italian Protests

name: Guy Fawkes Mask
description_html: The Guy Fawkes mask, popularized by the graphic novel and film V for Vendetta, has become a global symbol of protest against authority, corruption, and censorship. First adopted by the hacktivist collective Anonymous in 2008 during Project Chanology, it offers both anonymity and a sense of unity for demonstrators. Since then, it has appeared in protests worldwide—from Occupy Wall Street to the Arab Spring—representing anti-establishment sentiment and collective resistance. Its distinctive, smiling visage has turned it into a universal emblem of dissent in the 21st century, allowing individuals to submerge their identity into a larger, faceless movement.

images.caption: Protesters wearing Guy Fawkes masks during Occupy Wall Street, New York, 2011
Supporters of Anonymous at a 'Million Mask March' in London
The evolution of the Guy Fawkes mask as a protest symbol (YouTube)

eyewitness: When you put the mask on, you aren't just one person anymore; you're part of an idea that can't be killed. (Anonymous activist, 2012)
Looking out at a crowd of hundreds of the same smiling face is both empowering and deeply unsettling for the authorities.

sources.title: The Mask of Anonymity

sources: Lewis, S. (2013). Digital Activism and the Guy Fawkes Mask. Journal of Political Iconography.

sources.title: Why we wear the mask: A history of the Million Mask March

name: Beer
description_html: In Ostritz, Germany, in June 2019, local residents used beer as a tool of community opposition against the far-right “Shield and Sword” music festival. After a court imposed an alcohol ban, villagers bought up more than 100 crates of beer in nearby shops to effectively dry out the local supply, while police confiscated a further 4,400 litres. In Botswana, beer has been central to dissent since a 30% alcohol levy was introduced in 2008. Workers and drinkers in Gaborone organized marches in 2009 and used informal shebeens to flout curfews, asserting personal freedoms against state intervention. Whether through tactical purchase or defiance of levies, beer serves as a medium to contest both political extremism and economic regulation.

images.caption: Residents of Ostritz loading beer crates to prevent festival-goers from purchasing them
Brewery workers marching against the alcohol levy in Gaborone
How a German village 'dried out' a neo-Nazi festival (YouTube)

eyewitness: We wanted to leave the Nazis high and dry. If there's no beer, they don't stay long. (Ostritz resident, 2019)
The levy didn't stop the drinking; it just turned every backyard into a site of political rebellion.

sources.title: The Village that Drank the Nazis Dry

sources: Mogalakwe, M. (2012). State-Society Relations in Botswana: The Alcohol Levy Controversy. African Studies Review.

sources.title: Alcohol as a Catalyst for Social Change

name: The Tractor
description_html: The tractor has emerged as a notable symbol of Ukrainian resistance during the 2022 invasion. Early in the conflict, viral videos and images showed Ukrainian farmers using tractors to tow away abandoned or captured Russian military vehicles, including tanks and armored personnel carriers. These scenes quickly became iconic, circulating widely on social media and inspiring memes, posters, and merchandise. The image of a humble farm vehicle dragging a multi-million dollar piece of high-tech weaponry became a potent symbol of David vs. Goliath defiance and the ingenuity of the national resistance. The "Ukrainian tractor pulling a tank" motif was even immortalized on official postage stamps, solidifying its place as a marker of the struggle for sovereignty.

images.caption: A Ukrainian tractor towing a captured Russian armored vehicle, 2022
Official Ukrainian postage stamp commemorating the 'Tractor Brigade'
Compilation: Farmers towing military equipment (YouTube)

eyewitness: It was surreal. You'd see a T-80 tank being pulled down a dirt road by a John Deere as if it were just another piece of scrap metal. (Witness, Kherson region, 2022)
The tractors gave us hope. It showed that even if you don't have a gun, you can still take something from the occupier.

sources.title: The Rise of the Ukrainian Tractor Brigade

sources: Fedorenko, K. (2023). Memes as Weapons: Digital Resistance in the Russo-Ukrainian War. Journal of Digital Sovereignty.

sources.title: Visualizing Victory: How the Tractor became an Icon

name: Sunflower Seeds
description_html: Sunflower seeds have emerged as a multifaceted protest symbol. In Ukraine, they became a global emblem of resistance after the 2022 Russian invasion, sparked by a viral video of a woman telling soldiers to carry seeds so flowers would grow when they died. The sunflower, Ukraine's national flower, became a sign of resilience in protest art and social media. In a different context, Chinese artist Ai Weiwei used 100 million hand-crafted porcelain sunflower seeds in his 2010 installation to critique political repression and collective conformity. Referencing Maoist propaganda—which depicted Chairman Mao as the sun and the people as sunflowers—his work reimagined the seed as a symbol of individuality and solidarity against the state.

images.caption: Protester holding a sunflower, now a global symbol of Ukrainian defiance
Porcelain sunflower seeds in Ai Weiwei's 'Sunflower Seeds' (2010) installation
The woman who told a Russian soldier to put seeds in his pocket (YouTube)

eyewitness: She spoke with such calm fury; it turned a simple seed into a curse for the invader and a promise of life for us. (Witness to the 2022 viral video)
Walking through Ai Weiwei's seeds, you realized that every single one was unique, yet they were all being stepped on. It was a powerful metaphor for the individual in China.

sources.title: Ai Weiwei: Sunflower Seeds at Tate Modern

sources: Zhurzhenko, T. (2022). The Sunflower as a Symbol of Ukrainian Resilience. European Journal of Cultural Studies.

sources.title: How a simple seed became a weapon of war

name: Toilet Brush
description_html: During Hamburg’s 2013–2014 protests—sparked by the threatened eviction of the Rote Flora social center and the creation of “danger zones” (Gefahrengebiete) with broad stop-and-search powers—a toilet brush became an unlikely symbol of dissent. After a viral video showed police confiscating a toilet brush from a protester's pocket during a search, the object was transformed into a tool of mockery & satire. Demonstrators began brandishing toilet brushes at rallies and featuring them in street art to highlight what they viewed as arbitrary policing and state overreach. The humble cleaning tool quickly became shorthand for the right to the city and resistance against the criminalization of everyday items in public spaces.

images.caption: Protesters in Hamburg holding toilet brushes aloft to mock police searches, 2014
Street art featuring a toilet brush outside the Rote Flora social center
Video: The 'Klobürste' (Toilet Brush) movement in Hamburg (YouTube)

eyewitness: When the police officer pulled the brush out of that guy's pocket and looked at it like it was a weapon, we all knew we had our new symbol. (Hamburg resident, 2014)
It was a way to laugh at the absurdity of being searched just for walking through your own neighborhood.

sources.title: The Toilet Brush: Symbol of the Hamburg Resistance

sources: Novy, J. (2014). The 'Right to the City' and its Appropriation in Hamburg. City: Analysis of Urban Trends, Culture, Theory, Policy.

sources.title: From Squats to Symbols: A History of Rote Flora

name: Winnie-the-Pooh
description_html: Winnie-the-Pooh became a playful stand-in for China’s Xi Jinping in 2013, after social-media users paired a photo of Xi and Barack Obama with an image of Pooh and Tigger. Beijing soon scrubbed Pooh memes and even blocked the 2018 film Christopher Robin as part of its anti-censorship efforts. The bear remains a fixture in protest culture; during the 2022 “White Paper” anti-lockdown demonstrations, Pooh was depicted holding a blank sheet—the movement’s symbol of censored speech. In 2023, a Taiwanese air-force patch depicting a Formosan black bear punching Pooh went viral, underscoring the character's role as a lighthearted emblem of defiance and national sovereignty.

images.caption: The original 2013 comparison between Xi Jinping, Obama, and Pooh/Tigger
The viral 2023 patch showing a Formosan bear punching Winnie-the-Pooh
Protest merchandise showing Pooh holding a blank white paper
Why China banned Winnie the Pooh (YouTube)

eyewitness: It started as a harmless joke, but the government's reaction made it a powerful symbol of their insecurity. (Shanghai resident, 2022)
Wearing a Pooh shirt became a way to say something without saying a single word that could get you arrested.

sources.title: The bear that scared the CCP

sources: Yang, G. (2023). The Power of Internet Memes in Chinese Social Movements. New Media & Society.

sources.title: The Visual Language of the 2022 Protests

name: Keffiyeh
description_html: The keffiyeh—a traditional Arab scarf—became a political emblem during Palestine’s 1936–39 Arab Revolt, when rebels wore it to show solidarity and hide their identities. The black-and-white pattern gained iconic status in the 1960s after PLO leader Yasser Arafat adopted it, turning the rural garment into a global mark of national identity. The pattern itself—featuring motifs representing fishnets, olive leaves, and trade routes—is deeply tied to the land. Today, Palestinians and their supporters worldwide wear the keffiyeh at demonstrations as a visible stand against occupation and injustice, making it one of the most recognized symbols of self-determination in the world.

images.caption: Yasser Arafat, whose specific way of folding the keffiyeh resembled the map of Palestine
The distinctive fishnet and sea-route patterns of the Palestinian keffiyeh
History and meaning of the Keffiyeh (YouTube)

eyewitness: Wearing the keffiyeh isn't just about a scarf; it's about carrying our history and our connection to the olive trees on our shoulders. (Palestinian activist, Ramallah)
In the 1930s, the rebels asked everyone in the cities to wear it so the British couldn't tell who was a fighter and who wasn't. It was our first act of mass camouflage.

sources.title: The Weaver's Resistance: History of the Keffiyeh

sources: Khalidi, R. (2006). The Iron Cage: The Story of the Palestinian Struggle for Statehood. Beacon Press.

sources.title: Why the Keffiyeh remains a global symbol of dissent

name: Mini Skirt
categories_protest: British Society for the Protection of Mini Skirts
description_html: The miniskirt became a symbol of female liberation and protest in the 1960s, closely linked to the rise of the feminist movement and the rejection of restrictive gender norms. Popularized by designers like Mary Quant, the miniskirt represented a break from traditional, conservative fashion and signaled women’s growing independence and bodily autonomy. A notable protest occurred in 1966 at the Dior headquarters in London. When Dior’s collection featured longer hemlines, a group called the “British Society for the Protection of Mini Skirts” gathered outside the show, wearing miniskirts and carrying placards with slogans like “Miniskirts forever!” and “Dior, don’t betray mini skirt.” This demonstration underscored the garment’s status as a symbol of women’s rights to self-expression and resistance against imposed standards of modesty.

images.caption: Members of the British Society for the Protection of Mini Skirts protesting at Dior, London, 1966
Models in Mary Quant miniskirts, a defining look of 1960s liberation
The fashion revolution: How the miniskirt changed the world (YouTube)

eyewitness: We weren't just protesting about clothes; we were protesting for the right to control how we appeared in the world. (Protest participant, 1966)
The shorter the skirt got, the more the older generation panicked. That's how we knew it was working.

sources.title: The Miniskirt: A History of Rebellion

sources: Quant, M. (1966). Quant by Quant. Cassell & Co. (Autobiography of the designer).

sources.title: The Day Women Protested Dior for Mini Skirts

name: Field Jacket
description_html: The field jacket, particularly the U.S. Army M-65 model, became a powerful symbol of protest and counterculture during the Vietnam War era. Originally designed as functional military gear, it was widely adopted by anti-war activists and returning veterans. By wearing surplus military jackets, protesters subverted the garment’s original meaning, transforming it from a symbol of military authority into a statement against war and government policy. Notable figures such as John Lennon and John Kerry wore field jackets at rallies, often customizing them with peace signs, slogans, and patches. The jacket’s ubiquity at demonstrations made it a visible marker of rebellion, disillusionment, and solidarity with those opposing military intervention.

images.caption: John Lennon wearing an army field jacket, subverting its military origin
Vietnam Veterans Against the War (VVAW) wearing field jackets during a protest
Fashion as Dissent: The M-65 in American Counterculture (YouTube)

eyewitness: Wearing the olive drab of the army while holding a peace sign felt like we were taking the war back from the politicians. (Anti-war activist, 1971)
For us veterans, wearing the field jacket at a rally was a way of saying 'I was there, and I'm telling you this is wrong.'

sources.title: The M-65: From Combat to Counterculture

sources: Lembcke, J. (1998). The Spitting Image: Myth, Memory, and the Legacy of Vietnam. NYU Press.

sources.title: The Politics of Surplus Clothing

name: The Beret
description_html: The beret has long served as a powerful symbol of protest and revolutionary identity around the world. It became iconic through figures like Che Guevara, whose use of the black beret helped link the garment to anti-imperialist struggle. In the United States, the Black Panther Party adopted the black beret in the late 1960s to signal unity, strength, and resistance to racial oppression. In South Africa, the red beret is the signature of the Economic Freedom Fighters (EFF), representing working-class solidarity. In Uganda, the red beret was adopted by Bobi Wine’s People Power movement, becoming such a strong symbol that the government banned civilians from wearing it in 2019.

images.caption: Alberto Korda’s iconic 'Guerrillero Heroico' portrait of Che Guevara
Members of the Black Panther Party in uniform black berets, 1960s
Economic Freedom Fighters supporters wearing red berets in South Africa
The power of the red beret in African politics (YouTube)

eyewitness: When we put on the beret, it wasn't just fashion. it was a declaration that we were disciplined, organized, and ready to fight for our community. (Former Black Panther member)
The government banned the red beret because they were afraid of its power; every person wearing one was a walking billboard for the revolution. (People Power activist, Kampala)

sources.title: The Aesthetics of Black Power

sources: Bloom, J. (2013). Black against Empire: The History and Politics of the Black Panther Party. University of California Press.

sources.title: Why Uganda's military banned the red beret

name: Leather Jacket
description_html: The leather jacket has become an enduring symbol of rebellion and protest, particularly in Western culture. In the 1960s and 1970s, the garment was embraced by countercultural groups, most notably the Black Panthers in the United States. They wore black leather jackets as a core part of their uniform to project strength, unity, and resistance to oppression. Simultaneously, punk movements in the U.K. and U.S. further cemented the leather jacket as a symbol of anti-establishment sentiment. Activists customized their jackets with slogans, patches, and studs to express political messages, transforming a protective garment into a mobile billboard for social change and individual defiance.

images.caption: Black Panther Party members in their signature leather jackets and berets
A punk leather jacket featuring political patches and hand-painted slogans
The uniform of rebellion: Leather in social movements (YouTube)

eyewitness: When we walked down the street in our leather jackets, the community saw a shield and the police saw a threat. That was the point. (Former Black Panther member, Oakland)
My jacket was my identity. Every patch I sewed on was a cause I believed in or a system I wanted to tear down.

sources.title: The Leather Jacket: A History of Dissent

sources: Hebdige, D. (1979). Subculture: The Meaning of Style. Routledge. (Analysis of punk symbolism).

sources.title: Visualizing the Black Power Movement

name: Jeans
description_html: Jeans shifted from 19th-century workwear to a global protest symbol in the 1950s-60s, when they became shorthand for youthful rebellion. In the U.S. civil-rights era, activists wore denim to signal solidarity with poor sharecroppers; Martin Luther King Jr. was arrested in Birmingham in 1963 wearing work jeans. In the USSR and Eastern Bloc, jeans were seen as a manifestation of Western capitalist values and were often restricted or forbidden. This symbolic power was highlighted during the 2006 “Jeans Revolution” in Belarus, where denim became an emblem for pro-democracy activists. Later, denim became a tool against sexual-violence myths: after a controversial 1999 Italian court ruling, activists launched “Denim Day” to oppose victim-blaming worldwide.

images.caption: Martin Luther King Jr. in denim workwear during his 1963 arrest
Activists holding denim fabric as a flag during the Jeans Revolution in Minsk
Protesters wearing jeans to support 'Denim Day' and oppose victim-blaming
History of Jeans: From Workwear to Warfare (YouTube)

eyewitness: In the 60s, wearing jeans to a march wasn't about being casual; it was about showing that we stood with the workers in the fields. (Civil Rights activist, 1963)
The police took away our flags in the square, so one of us took off his denim shirt and waved it like a banner. That's how the revolution got its name. (Minsk protester, 2006)

sources.title: The Denim Council: Civil Rights and the Politics of Dress

sources: Sullivan, J. (2006). Jeans: A Cultural History of an American Icon. Gotham Books.

sources.title: The History of Denim Day

name: Sunflower
description_html: Sunflowers have served as potent protest symbols across diverse historical contexts. In Taiwan, the 2014 Sunflower Student Movement adopted the flower after a florist donated hundreds to students occupying the Legislative Yuan. Chosen for its heliotropic nature—turning toward the sun—it became a symbol of transparency and resistance against a trade agreement with China. As Ukraine’s national flower, its symbolic power surged in 2022 following a viral video of a woman telling soldiers to carry sunflower seeds so blooms would sprout where they died, turning it into a worldwide emblem of resilience. Historically, the sunflower also aided the U.S. women’s suffrage movement; in 1867, Elizabeth Cady Stanton and Susan B. Anthony wore sunflower pins in Kansas, establishing yellow as a defining color for the fight for equality.

images.caption: Students occupying the Legislative Yuan in Taipei surrounded by sunflowers, 2014
Vintage yellow sunflower pin used by American suffragists
A protester in London holding sunflowers in solidarity with Ukraine, 2022
Documentary: The Sunflower Movement and Taiwan's Democracy (YouTube)

eyewitness: The sunflowers stood out against the dark wood of the chamber—they looked like little bursts of hope in a very tense place. (Student protester, Taipei, 2014)
We wore yellow because it was the color of the sunflower, the color of the sun that lights the way for justice. (Suffrage historian excerpt)

sources.title: The Yellow Ribbon and the Sunflower: Suffrage Symbols

sources: Ho, M. (2015). The Sunflower Movement: Origins and Consequences. Journal of East Asian Studies.

sources.title: Why the Sunflower belongs to Ukraine

name: Carnation
description_html: Carnations are among the most recognizable protest flowers. During Portugal’s Carnation Revolution on 25 April 1974, civilians and rebel soldiers placed red carnations in rifle barrels, turning a military coup into a largely bloodless uprising that ended decades of dictatorship. Red carnations also symbolize labour solidarity, worn on International Workers’ Day to represent socialist ideals. In the United States, Bernie Boston’s 1967 “Flower Power” photo immortalized a Vietnam War protester inserting a carnation into a soldier’s gun. Meanwhile, in Nazi-occupied Netherlands, white carnations quietly signaled resistance and loyalty to the exiled royal family. Whether red for revolution or white for quiet defiance, the carnation serves as a vivid botanical plea for peace and justice.

images.caption: Soldiers with red carnations in their rifles, Lisbon, 1974
A protester placing a flower in a military rifle barrel, 1967
The white carnation, a symbol of Dutch resistance during WWII
Documentary: The Day of the Carnations (YouTube)

eyewitness: A flower girl started handing them out to the soldiers, and suddenly the guns weren't scary anymore. They were covered in flowers. (Lisbon resident, 1974)
Wearing the white carnation was our secret way of saying 'we haven't forgotten our Queen' right in front of the occupiers' faces.

sources.title: April 25: The Carnation Revolution

sources: Maxwell, K. (1995). The Making of Portuguese Democracy. Cambridge University Press.

sources.title: The Story Behind the Flower Power Image

name: Lily
description_html: The lily, specifically the native Formosan lily, became a powerful protest symbol during Taiwan’s 1990 Wild Lily Student Movement. Students wore white lilies and created large replicas of the flower to represent democracy, purity, and resilience. The movement, which called for direct presidential elections and political reform, marked a turning point in Taiwan’s democratization. The choice of the Formosan lily reflected its cultural significance as a symbol of honor and vitality, thriving even in harsh environments. It remains closely associated with peaceful protest and the dismantling of the one-party state system.

images.caption: Students with white lilies at Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, 1990
A giant white lily sculpture erected by protesters as a symbol of purity
The movement that shaped Taiwan's democracy (YouTube)

eyewitness: We chose the wild lily because it is native to our land and grows everywhere, from the coast to the highest mountains. It represented the strength of the people. (Movement organizer, 1990)
Seeing thousands of students sitting in the square with white flowers was a moment of profound hope for our future.

sources.title: The Wild Lily Revolution: 1990

sources: Wright, T. (2001). The Perils of Protest: State-Society Relations in Post-Martial Law Taiwan.

sources.title: From Wild Lily to Sunflower: Floral Symbols in Taiwan

name: Red & White Flowers
description_html: During Belarus’s 2020 protests against Alexander Lukashenko, women dressed in white formed “lines of solidarity” and handed out white and red flowers—typically carnations or roses. The colors specifically matched the banned white-red-white flag of the opposition, turning simple bouquets into a peaceful counterpart to state force. Under the slogan “Riot police have batons, we have flowers,” these floral chains spread nationwide as a symbol of non-violence and unity. By using flowers when traditional banners were confiscated, activists created a highly visible and difficult-to-repress marker of hope amid severe government crackdowns on political symbols.

images.caption: Women in white holding red and white flowers during the 2020 Minsk protests
A demonstrator offering a flower to a riot police officer as a gesture of non-violence
The 'Women in White' movement in Belarus (YouTube)

eyewitness: We wore white to show our intentions were pure, and the flowers were our only weapons. It’s hard for a soldier to hit a woman holding a rose. (Minsk activist, 2020)
Every red and white carnation was a silent way of waving our forbidden flag without actually carrying a piece of cloth.

sources.title: Flowers vs. Batons: The Women of Belarus

sources: Gapova, E. (2021). The 'Women in White' and the Belarusian Revolution of 2020. Slavic Review.

sources.title: The Semiotics of Red and White in Belarusian Dissent
